trans-unit.source: Search for data in Operational Insights
trans-unit.target: Search for data in Operational Insights

trans-unit.source: You can use the log search in Microsoft Azure Operational Insights to find data that you’re looking for
trans-unit.target: You can use the log search in Microsoft Azure Operational Insights to find data that you’re looking for

trans-unit.source: Search for data in Operational Insights
trans-unit.target: Search for data in Operational Insights

trans-unit.source: At the core of Microsoft Azure Operational Insights is the log search feature which allows you to combine and correlate any machine data from multiple sources within your environment.
trans-unit.target: At the core of Microsoft Azure Operational Insights is the log search feature which allows you to combine and correlate any machine data from multiple sources within your environment.

trans-unit.source: Solutions are also powered by log search to bring you metrics pivoted around a particular problem area.
trans-unit.target: Solutions are also powered by log search to bring you metrics pivoted around a particular problem area.

trans-unit.source: On the Search page, you can create a query, and then when you search, you can filter the results by using facet controls.
trans-unit.target: On the Search page, you can create a query, and then when you search, you can filter the results by using facet controls.

trans-unit.source: You can also create advanced queries to transform, filter, and report on your results.
trans-unit.target: You can also create advanced queries to transform, filter, and report on your results.

trans-unit.source: Common log search queries appear on most solution pages.
trans-unit.target: Common log search queries appear on most solution pages.

trans-unit.source: Throughout the Operational Insights console, you can click tiles or drill in to other items to view details about the item by using log search.
trans-unit.target: Throughout the Operational Insights console, you can click tiles or drill in to other items to view details about the item by using log search.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll walk through examples to cover all the basics when you use log search.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll walk through examples to cover all the basics when you use log search.

trans-unit.source: We'll start with simple, practical examples and then build on them so that you can get an understanding of practical use cases about how to use the syntax to extract the insights you want from the data.
trans-unit.target: We'll start with simple, practical examples and then build on them so that you can get an understanding of practical use cases about how to use the syntax to extract the insights you want from the data.

trans-unit.source: When you conduct log searches in Operational Insights, you'll use the following techniques:
trans-unit.target: When you conduct log searches in Operational Insights, you'll use the following techniques:

trans-unit.source: Use the max and min functions with the measure command
trans-unit.target: Use the max and min functions with the measure command

trans-unit.source: Use the avg function with the measure command
trans-unit.target: Use the avg function with the measure command

trans-unit.source: After you've familiar with search techniques, you can review the [Search syntax reference](#search-syntax-reference) and the [Search field and facet reference](#search-field-and-facet-reference).
trans-unit.target: After you've familiar with search techniques, you can review the [Search syntax reference](#search-syntax-reference) and the [Search field and facet reference](#search-field-and-facet-reference).

trans-unit.source: The first thing to know is that the first part of a search query, before any “|” vertical pipe character, is always a *filter*.
trans-unit.target: The first thing to know is that the first part of a search query, before any “|” vertical pipe character, is always a *filter*.

trans-unit.source: You can think of it as a WHERE clause in TSQL--it determines *what* subset of data to pull out of the Operational Insights data store.
trans-unit.target: You can think of it as a WHERE clause in TSQL--it determines *what* subset of data to pull out of the Operational Insights data store.

trans-unit.source: Searching from a the data store is largely about specifying the characteristics of the data that you want to extract, so it is natural that a query would start with the WHERE clause.
trans-unit.target: Searching from a the data store is largely about specifying the characteristics of the data that you want to extract, so it is natural that a query would start with the WHERE clause.

trans-unit.source: The most basic filters you can use are *keywords*, such as ‘error’ or ‘timeout’, or a computer name.
trans-unit.target: The most basic filters you can use are *keywords*, such as ‘error’ or ‘timeout’, or a computer name.

trans-unit.source: These types of simple queries generally return diverse shapes of data within the same result set.
trans-unit.target: These types of simple queries generally return diverse shapes of data within the same result set.

trans-unit.source: This is because Operational Insights has different *types* of data in the system.
trans-unit.target: This is because Operational Insights has different *types* of data in the system.

trans-unit.source: In the Operational Insights portal, click **Search Data Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: In the Operational Insights portal, click **Search Data Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: In the query field, type `error` and then click **Search**.
trans-unit.target: In the query field, type `error` and then click **Search**.

trans-unit.source: For example, the query for `error` in the following image returned 100,000 **Event** records (collected by Log Management), 18 **ConfigurationAlert** records (generated by Configuration Assessment) and 12 **ConfigurationChange** records (captured by the Change Tracking).
trans-unit.target: For example, the query for `error` in the following image returned 100,000 **Event** records (collected by Log Management), 18 **ConfigurationAlert** records (generated by Configuration Assessment) and 12 **ConfigurationChange** records (captured by the Change Tracking).

trans-unit.source: These filters are not really object types/classes.
trans-unit.target: These filters are not really object types/classes.

trans-unit.source: *Type* is just a tag, or a property, or a string/name/category, that is attached to a piece of data.
trans-unit.target: *Type* is just a tag, or a property, or a string/name/category, that is attached to a piece of data.

trans-unit.source: Some documents in the system are tagged as **Type:ConfigurationAlert** and some are tagged as **Type:PerfHourly**, or **Type:Event**, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Some documents in the system are tagged as **Type:ConfigurationAlert** and some are tagged as **Type:PerfHourly**, or **Type:Event**, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Each search result, document, record, or entry displays all the raw properties and their values for each of those pieces of data, and you can use those field names to specify in the filter when you want to retrieve only the records where the field has that given value.
trans-unit.target: Each search result, document, record, or entry displays all the raw properties and their values for each of those pieces of data, and you can use those field names to specify in the filter when you want to retrieve only the records where the field has that given value.

trans-unit.source: *Type* is really just a field that all records have, it is not different from any other field.
trans-unit.target: *Type* is really just a field that all records have, it is not different from any other field.

trans-unit.source: This was established based on the value of the Type field.
trans-unit.target: This was established based on the value of the Type field.

trans-unit.target: That record will have a different shape or form.

trans-unit.source: Incidentally, **Type=PerfHourly**, or **Type=Event** is also the syntax that you need to learn to query for hourly performance data aggregates or events.
trans-unit.target: Incidentally, **Type=PerfHourly**, or **Type=Event** is also the syntax that you need to learn to query for hourly performance data aggregates or events.

trans-unit.source: You can use either a colon (:) or a equal sign (=) after the field name and before the value.
trans-unit.target: You can use either a colon (:) or a equal sign (=) after the field name and before the value.

trans-unit.source: **Type:Event** and **Type=Event** are equivalent in meaning, you can chose the style you prefer.
trans-unit.target: **Type:Event** and **Type=Event** are equivalent in meaning, you can chose the style you prefer.

trans-unit.source: So, if the Type=PerfHourly records have a field called 'CounterName', then you can write a query resembling `Type=PerfHourly CounterName="% Processor Time"`.
trans-unit.target: So, if the Type=PerfHourly records have a field called 'CounterName', then you can write a query resembling `Type=PerfHourly CounterName="% Processor Time"`.

trans-unit.source: This will give you only the performance data where the performance counter name is "% Processor Time".
trans-unit.target: This will give you only the performance data where the performance counter name is "% Processor Time".

trans-unit.source: To search for processor time performance data
trans-unit.target: To search for processor time performance data

trans-unit.target: In the search query field, type `Type=PerfHourly CounterName="% Processor Time"`

trans-unit.source: You can also be more specific and use **InstanceName=_'Total'** in the query, which is a Windows performance counter.
trans-unit.target: You can also be more specific and use **InstanceName=_'Total'** in the query, which is a Windows performance counter.

trans-unit.target: You can also select a facet and another **field:value**.

trans-unit.source: Your query now becomes `Type=PerfHourly CounterName=”% Processor Time” InstanceName=”_Total”`
trans-unit.target: Your query now becomes `Type=PerfHourly CounterName=”% Processor Time” InstanceName=”_Total”`

trans-unit.source: This is because all the filters in the query are evaluated as being in *AND* with each other.
trans-unit.target: This is because all the filters in the query are evaluated as being in *AND* with each other.

trans-unit.source: Effectively, the more fields you add to the criteria, you get less, more specific and refined results.
trans-unit.target: Effectively, the more fields you add to the criteria, you get less, more specific and refined results.

trans-unit.source: For example, the query `Type=Event EventLog="Windows PowerShell"` is identical to `Type=Event AND EventLog="Windows PowerShell"`.
trans-unit.target: For example, the query `Type=Event EventLog="Windows PowerShell"` is identical to `Type=Event AND EventLog="Windows PowerShell"`.

trans-unit.source: It returns all events that were logged in and collected from the Windows PowerShell event log.
trans-unit.target: It returns all events that were logged in and collected from the Windows PowerShell event log.

trans-unit.source: If you add a filter multiple times by repeatedly selecting the same facet, then the issue is purely cosmetic--it might clutter the Search bar, but it still returns the same results because the implicit AND operator is always there.
trans-unit.target: If you add a filter multiple times by repeatedly selecting the same facet, then the issue is purely cosmetic--it might clutter the Search bar, but it still returns the same results because the implicit AND operator is always there.

trans-unit.source: You can easily reverse the implicit AND operator by using a NOT operator explicitly.
trans-unit.target: You can easily reverse the implicit AND operator by using a NOT operator explicitly.

trans-unit.source: `Type:Event NOT(EventLog:"Windows PowerShell")` or it's equivalent `Type=Event EventLog!="Windows PowerShell"` return all events from all other logs that are NOT the Windows PowerShell log.
trans-unit.target: `Type:Event NOT(EventLog:"Windows PowerShell")` or it's equivalent `Type=Event EventLog!="Windows PowerShell"` return all events from all other logs that are NOT the Windows PowerShell log.

trans-unit.source: Or, you can use other Boolean operator such as ‘OR’.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can use other Boolean operator such as ‘OR’.

trans-unit.source: Although you can control the time interval graphically, and most times you might want to do that, there are advantages to including a time filter directly into the query.
trans-unit.target: Although you can control the time interval graphically, and most times you might want to do that, there are advantages to including a time filter directly into the query.

trans-unit.source: For example, this works great with dashboards where you can override the time for each tile, regardless of the *global* time selector on the dashboard page.
trans-unit.target: For example, this works great with dashboards where you can override the time for each tile, regardless of the *global* time selector on the dashboard page.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Time Matters in Dashboard](http://cloudadministrator.wordpress.com/2014/10/19/system-center-advisor-restarted-time-matters-in-dashboard-part-6/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Time Matters in Dashboard](http://cloudadministrator.wordpress.com/2014/10/19/system-center-advisor-restarted-time-matters-in-dashboard-part-6/).

trans-unit.source: When filtering by time, keep in mind that you get results for the *intersection* of the two time periods: the one specified in the Operational Insights portal (S1) and the one specified in the query (S2).
trans-unit.target: When filtering by time, keep in mind that you get results for the *intersection* of the two time periods: the one specified in the Operational Insights portal (S1) and the one specified in the query (S2).

trans-unit.source: This means, if the time periods don’t intersect, for example in the Operational Insights portal where you choose **This week** and in the query where you define **last week**, then there is no intersection and you won't receive any results.
trans-unit.target: This means, if the time periods don’t intersect, for example in the Operational Insights portal where you choose **This week** and in the query where you define **last week**, then there is no intersection and you won't receive any results.

trans-unit.source: When you're searching for data, you'll want to refine your search query and have a good level of control over the results.
trans-unit.target: When you're searching for data, you'll want to refine your search query and have a good level of control over the results.

trans-unit.source: When results are retrieved, you can apply commands to transform them.
trans-unit.target: When results are retrieved, you can apply commands to transform them.

trans-unit.source: Commands in Operational Insights searches *must* follow after the vertical pipe character (|).
trans-unit.target: Commands in Operational Insights searches *must* follow after the vertical pipe character (|).

trans-unit.source: A filter must always be the first part of a query string.
trans-unit.target: A filter must always be the first part of a query string.

trans-unit.source: It defines the data set you're working with and then "pipes" those results into a command.
trans-unit.target: It defines the data set you're working with and then "pipes" those results into a command.

trans-unit.source: You can then use the pipe to add additional commands.
trans-unit.target: You can then use the pipe to add additional commands.

trans-unit.source: This is loosely similar to the Windows PowerShell pipeline.
trans-unit.target: This is loosely similar to the Windows PowerShell pipeline.

trans-unit.source: In general, the Operational Insights search language tries to follow PowerShell style and guidelines to make it similar to the IT pros, and to ease the learning curve.
trans-unit.target: In general, the Operational Insights search language tries to follow PowerShell style and guidelines to make it similar to the IT pros, and to ease the learning curve.

trans-unit.source: Commands have names of verbs so you can easily tell what they do.
trans-unit.target: Commands have names of verbs so you can easily tell what they do.

trans-unit.source: The sort command allows you to define the sorting order by one or multiple fields.
trans-unit.target: The sort command allows you to define the sorting order by one or multiple fields.

trans-unit.source: Even if you don’t use it, by default, a time descending order is enforced.
trans-unit.target: Even if you don’t use it, by default, a time descending order is enforced.

trans-unit.source: The most recent results are always at the top of search results.
trans-unit.target: The most recent results are always at the top of search results.

trans-unit.source: MEASURE is one of the most versatile commands in Operational Insights searches.
trans-unit.target: MEASURE is one of the most versatile commands in Operational Insights searches.

trans-unit.source: It allows you to apply statistical *functions* to your data and aggregate results grouped by a given field.
trans-unit.target: It allows you to apply statistical *functions* to your data and aggregate results grouped by a given field.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple statistical functions that Measure supports.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple statistical functions that Measure supports.

trans-unit.source: The first statistical function to work with, and one of the simplest to understand is the *count()* function.
trans-unit.target: The first statistical function to work with, and one of the simplest to understand is the *count()* function.

trans-unit.source: Results from any search query such as `Type=Event`, show filters also called facets on the left side of search results.
trans-unit.target: Results from any search query such as `Type=Event`, show filters also called facets on the left side of search results.

trans-unit.source: The filters show a distribution of values by a given field for the results in the search executed.
trans-unit.target: The filters show a distribution of values by a given field for the results in the search executed.

trans-unit.source: However, **Computer** is just a field used *in* each piece of data – there are no relational databases involved and there is no separate **Computer** object anywhere.
trans-unit.target: However, **Computer** is just a field used *in* each piece of data – there are no relational databases involved and there is no separate **Computer** object anywhere.

trans-unit.source: Just the values *in* the data can describe which entity generated them, and a number of other characteristics and aspects of the data – hence the term *facet*.
trans-unit.target: Just the values *in* the data can describe which entity generated them, and a number of other characteristics and aspects of the data – hence the term *facet*.
